The UK needs at least 25 000 000 kW of electrical power at any time.
A nuclear power station has an electrical power output of 2 400 000 kW
Calculate how many nuclear power stations are needed to provide 25 000 000 kW of electrical power.
environmental issues caused by generating electricity using nuclear power stations.
The UK currently generates a lot of electricity by burning natural gas. This process releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
shows how the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has changed over the past 115 years.
shows how the global temperature has changed over the past 115 years.

Different radioactive isotopes have different half-lives.
Half the time taken for all of the nuclei in a sample to decay.
The time taken for half the nuclei in a sample to decay.
The time taken for one nucleus to split in half.
shows the half-life of some different isotopes of carbon.
Which isotope is the least stable?
Workers in nuclear power stations must be aware of nuclear irradiation and radioactive contamination.
line from each term to an example of the term.
Exposure to a beam of gamma rays
Exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the Sun
Accidental transfer of plutonium onto a human body
Why are workers required to walk across a sticky floor before leaving the nuclear power station?
To remove alpha particles from their shoes.
To remove gamma radiation from their shoes.
To remove radioactive dust from their shoes.
The places where people work and live contribute to the nuclear radiation they are exposed to.
shows the mean daily dose of radiation caused by two different jobs.
Calculate the number of days a nuclear power station worker must work before receiving the same dose that an aeroplane pilot receives in one day.
The process of nuclear fission takes place in nuclear power stations.
The process of nuclear fusion takes place in the Sun.
line from each process to its fuel.
The process of nuclear fusion results in the release of energy.
(a) (i) Describe the process of nuclear fusion.
(ii) Where does nuclear fusion happen naturally?

(b) For many years, scientists have tried to produce a controlled nuclear fusion reaction that lasts long enough to be useful. However, the experimental fusion reactors use more energy than they produce.
reason why nuclear fusion reactors are not used to produce energy in a nuclear power station.
reason why scientists continue to try to develop a practical nuclear fusion reactor.

(b) Use the information in the table to explain why an atom has no overall electrical charge.

Uranium-235 is used as a fuel inside a nuclear reactor.
Inside the reactor, atoms of uranium-235 are split and energy is released.
(i) How is the structure of an atom of uranium-235 different from the structure of an atom of uranium-238?
(ii) The nucleus of a uranium-235 atom must absorb a particle before the atom is able to split.
What type of particle is absorbed?
(iii) The nucleus of an atom splits into smaller parts in a reactor.
What name is given to this process?
Nuclear fission and nuclear fusion are two processes that release energy.
(a) (i) Use the correct answer from the box to complete each sentence.

Nuclear fusion takes place within a _____________________________ .
way in which the process of nuclear fusion differs from the process of nuclear fission.

Ba-139 decays by beta decay to lanthanum-139 (La-139).
Complete the nuclear equation that represents the decay of Ba-139 to La-139.

precaution taken to reduce the hazard caused by radioactive waste from power stations.
generate electricity every day of the year.

(ii) What is released during both nuclear fission and nuclear fusion?

What do the nuclei of different plutonium isotopes have in common?

(ii) How does nuclear fission lead to a chain reaction?

benefit to the environment of using a concentrated fuel like uranium to generate electricity rather than using the energy from coal.

of the gamma radiation emitted by a source depends on the energy of the radiation. The energy of the gamma radiation is given in units called electron-volts.
(i) Which of the materials shown is least effective at absorbing gamma radiation?
Use the information in the graph to give a reason for your answer.
(ii) For gamma radiation of energy 1.5 million electron-volts, how many times more effective is steel than water at absorbing the radiation? Show clearly how you obtain your answer.
(c) Scientists in the early twentieth century thought that atoms were made up of electrons scattered inside a ball of positive charge. This was called the ‘plum-pudding’ model of the atom.
Rutherford and Marsden did an experiment, in which a beam of alpha particles was aimed at a thin sheet of gold.
Explain how the results of this experiment led to a new model of the atom.
You may include one or more diagrams in your answer.
At the very high temperatures in the sun, hydrogen is converted into helium. It takes four hydrogen nuclei to produce one helium nucleus.
The table shows the relative masses of hydrogen and helium nuclei.
(a) Use these figures to calculate what happens to the mass of the sun as hydrogen is converted to helium.
(b) Use your answer to part (a) to explain how the sun has been able to radiate huge amounts of energy for billions of years.
The first commercial nuclear power station in the world was built at Calder Hall in Cumbria.
The atoms produced by the fission of uranium are also radioactive. The used fuel is sent to a reprocessing plant where it can be safely treated.
(i) Calder Hall power station is next to the Sellafield reprocessing plant. Suggest an advantage of having the two plants close together.
(ii) One of the radioactive products is iodine-138. This has a half-life of 6 seconds.
A sample of radioactive material contains 2000 atoms of iodine-138.
How long will it take for the number of iodine-131 atoms to decrease to 125?
